item.title: Numeral Plural
item.description: Some masculine words have specials rules, taking a different plural ending. This happens when these words follow a number or expressions such as –∫–æ–ª–∫–æ (how many?) or –Ω—è–∫–æ–ª–∫–æ (a few). In these cases, they will end with -a. “–µ–¥–∏–Ω –º–µ—Å–µ—Ü” - one month “–¥–≤–∞ –º–µ—Å–µ—Ü–∞” - two months “–µ–¥–∏–Ω –¥–µ–Ω” - one day “–Ω—è–∫–æ–ª–∫–æ –¥–µ–Ω–∞*” - a few days This is called the numeral plural or counting form (–±—Ä–æ–π–Ω–∞ —Ñ–æ—Ä–º–∞). This only applies to masculine nouns that do not represent people.

item.title: Bulgarian Closed Questions
item.description: Asking a closed question (one that can be answered with yes or no) is quite simple. Use the –ª–∏ particle, usually added after the verb With the verb to be (—Å—ä–º) in the present tense, it is placed before Examples: –ò–º–∞ –ª–∏ –∫–æ—Ç–∫–∞? - Is there a cat? –ò–º–∞—à –ª–∏ –∫—É—á–µ? - Do you have a dog? –ú–æ–º—á–µ –ª–∏ —Å–∏? - Are you a boy?

item.title: Bulgarian There Is
item.description: The 3rd person singular of –∏–º–∞–º is also used to mean ’there is’. Unlike English it remains singular even when followed by a plural: –ò–º–∞ –∫–æ—Ç–∫–∞ - There is a cat –ò–º–∞ –º–Ω–æ–≥–æ –∫–æ—Ç–∫–∏ - There are many cats –ù—è–º–∞ –∫–æ—Ç–∫–∏ - There are no cats References

item.title: Bulgarian To Have Or Not To Have
item.description: To Have Or Not To Have –ò–º–∞–º is the verb ’to have' Usually a verb can be negated using the –Ω–µ particle In the case of –∏–º–∞–º there is a specific verb: –Ω—è–º–∞–º –ò–º–∞–º –∫–æ—Ç–∫–∞ - I have a cat –ò—è–º–∞–º –∫–æ—Ç–∫–∞ - I don’t have a cat Conjugation of both verbs at the present tense: –∏–º–∞–º –Ω—è–º–∞–º I –∞–∑ –∏–º–∞–º –Ω—è–º–∞–º you —Ç–∏ –∏–º–∞—à –Ω—è–º–∞—à he/she/it —Ç–æ–π/—Ç—è/—Ç–æ –∏–º–∞ –Ω—è–º–∞ we –Ω–∏–µ –∏–º–∞–º–µ –Ω—è–º–∞–º–µ you –≤–∏–µ –∏–º–∞—Ç–µ –Ω—è–º–∞—Ç–µ they —Ç–µ –∏–º–∞—Ç –Ω—è–º–∞—Ç This is the standard example of conjugation of verbs of the 3rd group.

item.title: Bulgarian Grammatical Gender
item.description: Masculine - Words ending in a consonant (including –π) (e.g. –º—ä–∂) Feminine - Words ending in -–∞ or -—è (e.g. –∂–µ–Ω–∞) Neutral - Words ending in -–æ or -–µ (e.g. –∫—É—á–µ) Words ending in -–∏, -—É, -—é are generally loan words (often coming from English) and are usually neutral –º–µ–Ω—é —Ç–∞–∫—Å–∏ Plurals Gender Ending Plural Masculine ‚Äëconsonant +–∏ or +–æ–≤–µ Feminine ‚Äë–∞ or ‚Äë—è ‚Äë–∏ Neutral ‚Äë–æ or ‚Äë–µ ‚Äëa or +—Ç–∞ Masculine Words –∏ is added to words that have one syllable –æ–≤–µ is added to words with more than one syllable Examples: –ü—Ä–∏—è—Ç–µ–ª - –ü—Ä–∏—è—Ç–µ–ª–∏ –ì—Ä–∞–¥ - –ì—Ä–∞–¥–æ–≤–µ –ú—ä–∂ - –ú—ä–∂–µ (an exception) Feminine Words The final -–∞ or -—è is replaced with –∏

item.title: Bulgarian Negation
item.description: Negation “–ù–µ” means no and it can be used to negate a sentence: “–ê–Ω–∞ –Ω–µ –µ –º—ä–∂” - Ana is not a man References

item.title: Indefinite Article
item.description: An indefinite article refers to non-specific nouns. You could say: I need a pen. I want an orange. In both cases, this does not refer to a specific pen or orange. Any will do. References

item.title: Conjugation
item.description: A verb can be conjugated with reference to the number, person, mood or tense. Examples: I teach English We teach English You teach English He teaches English She teaches English They teach English References

item.title: Citation Form
item.description: In Bulgarian, citation form is used to refer to a verb or to look it up in a dictionary. It is different from the infinitive in a grammatical sense. For example: “to be” is “—Å—ä–º” –°—ä–º is used for the citation form and for “I am” References

item.title: Adverb
item.description: An adverb is a word that modifies a verb (he sings loudly), an adjective (very tall), another adverb or even a whole sentence (fortunately, I had brought an umbrella). References

item.title: Infinitive
item.description: Infinitives are a special form of verbs that can be used as a noun, adjective or adverb. They are usually made by adding the word to before the base verb. They are useful when discussion actions without actually doing the action: I want to go home. I like to write in English. Example: I need to win. Today, we win. In the first sentence, the infinitive form of the verb win is used.

item.title: Verb
item.description: A verb is a word that describes what the subject of the sentence is doing. They can indicate (physical or mental) actions, occurrences and states of being. Jeff builds a house. Anita is thinking about horses. True love exists. References

item.title: Bulgarian Conjugation
item.description: In Bulgarian verbs are conjugated according to the subject (I, you, …) and the tense (past, present, …). This conjugation is applied to the ending of the verb. References

Bulgarian Verbs
item.description: Verbs do not have an infinitive form. When referring to a verb, use the first person conjugation of that verb. Here are examples Bulgarian the citation form “to be”. Example: “to be” is “—Å—ä–º” –°—ä–º is used for the citation form and for “I am” Two conjugations of “—Å—ä–º”: I am - –ê–∑ —Å—ä–º he/she/it is - —Ç–æ–π/—Ç—è/—Ç–æ –µ Examples: “–¢–æ–π –µ –º—ä–∂” - He is a man “–¢—è –µ –∂–µ–Ω–∞” - She is a woman “–¢–æ–≤–∞ –µ –∫—É—á–µ” - This is a dog Since the conjugations are unique to each subject, the pronoun can be left out:

item.title: Bulgarian Articles
item.description: In English there are 2 types of articles: Definite Indefinite There is no definite article in Bulgarian: “–∂–µ–Ω–∞” and “–∫—É—á–µ” are used alone to refer to “a woman” and “a dog”: “–¢—É –µ –∂–µ–Ω–∞” - She is a woman “–ê–∑ –∏–º–∞–º –∫—É—á–µ” - I have a dog References

item.title: Adjective
item.description: Adjectives are words that describe the qualities or states of being of nouns. Examples: Rob wore a beautiful hat. Furry dogs may overhead in the summertime. My cake should have sixteen candles. The scariest villain of all time is Darth Vader. References

item.title: Noun
item.description: A noun is a word that refers to a person, place, thing or idea. References

item.title: Pronoun
item.description: A pronoun is a word that stands in a for noun, often to avoid the need to repeat the same noun over and over. Use this when your reader/listener already knows which nouns you are referring to. Example: I have a dog. He’s brown and white. References

item.title: Definite Article
item.description: A definite article refers to a specific noun. You could say: The man’s dog barked at me. I lent my sister the book when I finished reading it. I didn’t go to the the party. References
